text: The Very Reverend Martin Thrower, 56, rector of Hadleigh, Suffolk, held his mobile phone over the top of a toilet cubicle, Norwich Crown Court heard. Thrower was arrested at a shopping centre in Ipswich in August 2016. He admitted two counts of voyeurism at a previous hearing and his sentence was suspended for 24 months. Thrower was ordered to complete a 60-day course to address sex offending behaviour, and must attend a further 30-day rehabilitation course. William Carter, prosecuting, said the rector was caught when a 17-year-old heard a noise above him as he sat on the toilet at the Buttermarket shopping centre. The teenager saw someone's hand holding a mobile phone that was filming him over the cubicle partition. He grabbed the phone and Thrower was arrested. Passing sentence earlier, judge Katharine Moore told Thrower he had been "well-regarded" by those he had helped, adding he had been a listening ear "in times of great sadness and some in happier times". She told him: "It seems to me that there has been a tendency throughout to attribute this persistent behaviour over a two-year period to a breakdown in your mental health. "I accept without reservation that you were working very hard. "I do not accept that your actions here though were anything other than an exercise of free choice repeated again and again when you thought you could get away with it in public lavatories." When Thrower was arrested, officers found three further videos recorded on the phone that day, including of two men who had not noticed they were being filmed. Thrower, of Church Street, Hadleigh, Suffolk, is rector of Hadleigh, Layham and Shelley. He has been suspended from all roles by the Diocese of St Edmundsbury in Ipswich. Stephen Nelson, mitigating, said Thrower was of previous good character and "deeply remorseful".
label: T1

text: The Very Reverend Martin Thrower , 56 , rector of Hadleigh , Suffolk , held his mobile phone over the top of a toilet cubicle , Norwich Crown Court heard . Thrower was arrested at a shopping centre in Ipswich in August 2016 . He admitted two counts of voyeurism at a previous hearing and his sentence was suspended for 24 months . Thrower was ordered to complete a 60 - day rehabilitation activity requirement, aimed at addressing his offending behaviour and preventing re-offending. As part of his sentence, he was also made the subject of a Sexual Harm Prevention Order (SHPO) for five years. This order imposes strict conditions, including restrictions on his use of internet-enabled devices and a prohibition on entering any public lavatories. Furthermore, Thrower was ordered to pay £2,500 in prosecution costs and a victim surcharge. The court heard details of how the Very Reverend Martin Thrower, who had served as the rector of Hadleigh in Suffolk for 15 years, had committed these offences. His reprehensible actions came to light when he was observed acting suspiciously at a shopping centre in Ipswich, specifically in the men's public toilets, leading to his arrest in August 2016. During the sentencing hearing at Norwich Crown Court, the presiding judge highlighted the profound breach of trust involved in Thrower's conduct, given his prominent and respected role within the Church of England and the local Hadleigh community. While acknowledging Thrower's early admission of guilt and expressions of remorse, the judge unequivocally underscored the seriousness of the voyeurism offences and the distress caused to his victims. The court took into account his previous good character and long service to the church as mitigating factors, which were instrumental in the decision to suspend his prison sentence for 24 months, but firmly emphasized the necessity for both punitive measures and active rehabilitation. This high-profile case sent ripples through the Hadleigh community and the wider diocese of St Edmundsbury and Ipswich, raising questions about accountability and the profound impact of such a conviction on a figure once held in high esteem.
label: T2

text: A clergyman who admitted filming a 17-year-old youth in a public toilet has been given a four month suspended sentence.
label: T3

text: The Very Reverend Martin Thrower, the 56-year-old rector of Hadleigh, Suffolk, was accused in Norwich Crown Court of holding his mobile phone over a toilet cubicle. His arrest occurred in August 2016 at an Ipswich shopping centre. At a previous hearing, he pleaded guilty to two charges of voyeurism, receiving a 24-month suspended sentence. As part of his sentence, Thrower was ordered to complete a 60-day course specifically designed to address sex offending behavior, in addition to a further 30-day rehabilitation program. Prosecutor William Carter explained that the rector was apprehended after a 17-year-old, using a toilet at the Buttermarket shopping centre, heard a sound above him. The teenager observed a hand holding a mobile phone that was filming him over the cubicle partition. He then seized the device, which led directly to Thrower's arrest. When handing down the sentence, Judge Katharine Moore acknowledged Thrower's generally "well-regarded" status among those he had assisted, describing him as having been a "listening ear" in both "times of great sadness and some in happier times." She stated her perception that his "persistent behavior over a two-year period" had consistently been blamed on a decline in his mental health. While acknowledging his dedication to his work, she firmly rejected the notion that his actions were anything but deliberate choices, made repeatedly in public restrooms when he believed he would not be caught. Upon his arrest, officers discovered three additional videos on his phone from that same day, two of which captured men seemingly unaware their privacy was being invaded. Thrower, whose address is Church Street, Hadleigh, Suffolk, serves as the rector for Hadleigh, Layham, and Shelley parishes. The Diocese of St Edmundsbury in Ipswich has suspended him from all his duties. His legal counsel, Stephen Nelson, stated that Thrower was of previous good character and expressed his client's profound remorse.
label: T4

text: World heavyweight champion Fury, 27, who expressed views on women, abortion and homosexuality, has been asked to attend a meeting in the new year. The BBBofC met to discuss the matter on Wednesday before informing Fury that he must meet with the board. The Briton has denied he is a homophobe and claimed he is "uniting the world". No exact date has been confirmed for the meeting. Meanwhile, Fury will not face police action following an inquiry into alleged homophobic comments. Greater Manchester Police (GMP) received a complaint earlier this week after statements made on the BBC's Victoria Derbyshire programme. But the force has recorded the comments as a "hate incident" as opposed to a hate crime. In the aftermath of his win against Ukrainian Wladimir Klitschko in Dusseldorf, Fury had said: "I'm not sexist. I believe a woman's best place is in the kitchen and on her back. That's my personal belief. Making me a good cup of tea, that's what I believe." The new world champion has also previously said it would only take the legalisation of paedophilia in addition to the decriminalisation of homosexuality and abortion to see "the devil come home". The Manchester fighter subsequently said: "Tyson Fury loves his fellow humans. He doesn't hate anybody." Fellow BBC Sports Personality of the Year nominee and long jump champion Greg Rutherford had planned to withdraw from this year's event over Fury's comments, before reversing his decision. Fury, who won the WBA, IBF and WBO titles on 28 November by beating Klitschko, was stripped of the IBF belt on Tuesday after choosing to face Klitschko in a rematch instead of the IBF's mandatory challenger, Ukrainian Vyacheslav Glazkov.

text: World heavyweight champion Fury , 27 , who expressed views on women , abortion and homosexuality , has been asked to attend a meeting in the new year . The BBBofC met to discuss the matter on Wednesday before informing Fury that he must meet with the board . The Briton has denied he is a homophobe and claimed he is " uniting the world " This upcoming meeting with the British Boxing Board of Control is expected to be a crucial one, as the organization seeks to address the widespread condemnation sparked by the boxer’s controversial remarks. Public outcry intensified following comments where Fury equated homosexuality and abortion with the end of the world, and made disparaging remarks about women. The firestorm led to significant pressure. Over 140,000 people signed an online petition calling for the Briton to be removed from the BBC Sports Personality of the Year shortlist. Despite the controversy, the BBC maintained Fury would remain on the list, citing that the decision was based on sporting achievement. This stance further fueled debate about the responsibility of public figures. Furthermore, his comments prompted an investigation by Greater Manchester Police (GMP). The police force confirmed they had received complaints regarding his comments, which were being assessed for potential hate crime implications. While the GMP later clarified no specific crime had been recorded, the police inquiry underscored the seriousness with which his remarks were viewed. Fury, who secured his world titles after defeating Wladimir Klitschko, has consistently maintained that his comments were taken out of context and that he is not a prejudiced individual, insisting he respects all people. Despite his defence, the ongoing controversy has cast a significant shadow over his boxing achievements and raised uncomfortable questions for the sport. The BBBofC meeting is anticipated to clarify whether Fury will face any disciplinary action, ranging from a reprimand to a fine or even a suspension, depending on the Board's assessment of his conduct and compliance with their code of ethics.
label: T2

text: Tyson Fury has been summoned by the British Boxing Board of Control to explain his recent controversial comments.
label: T3

text: Heavyweight boxing champion Tyson Fury, 27, known for his opinions on women, abortion, and homosexuality, has been summoned to a meeting with the British Boxing Board of Control (BBBofC) early next year. The BBBofC decided this after a Wednesday discussion. Fury denies being homophobic, asserting he is "uniting the world," though no precise date for the meeting has been set. Meanwhile, Fury will not face criminal charges from Greater Manchester Police (GMP) regarding alleged homophobic remarks. GMP received a complaint about his statements on the BBC's Victoria Derbyshire programme but classified them as a "hate incident" rather than a "hate crime." Following his victory over Wladimir Klitschko in Dusseldorf, Fury stated: "I'm not sexist. I believe a woman's best place is in the kitchen and on her back. That's my personal belief. Making me a good cup of tea, that's what I believe." The new world champion had also previously claimed that the legalisation of paedophilia, alongside the decriminalisation of homosexuality and abortion, would signal "the devil come home." Subsequently, the Manchester-born fighter clarified, "Tyson Fury loves his fellow humans. He doesn't hate anybody." Greg Rutherford, a fellow nominee for BBC Sports Personality of the Year and a long jump champion, initially intended to withdraw from the event due to Fury's comments but later changed his mind. Furthermore, Fury, who captured the WBA, IBF, and WBO titles on November 28 by defeating Klitschko, was stripped of his IBF belt on Tuesday. text: Ashley Broomhall trekked to the summit of 3,560ft (1,085m) Snowdon in Snowdonia before tackling Ben Nevis. It took him seven hours to walk up and down the 4,406ft (1,344m) Scottish peak near Fort William. On the way up he had a snowball fight with other walkers. He now plans to walk 3,208ft (978m) Scafell Pike in the Lake District. Mr Broomhall, from Whitchurch in Shropshire, has been doing the walks to raise money for Cancer Research UK. He set himself the peaks challenge after his mother was diagnosed with cancer. The 28-year-old has been a member of Star Wars costuming club the 501st UK Garrison for more than five years. Members attend events across the UK dressed in "movie-accurate" costumes to raise funds for charity. But Mr Broomhall had to make some modifications to his outfit to make it move more freely on the ascents and descents of Snowdon and Ben Nevis, which were done this summer. For safety reasons, he wore walking boots because his costume footwear was not suitable for the terrain involved and was accompanied by friends. Dressed as an Imperial stormtrooper and carrying a UK Garrison flag, Mr Broomhall said he drew more than his fair share of funny looks tackling Ben Nevis, Scotland highest Munro and Britain's tallest mountain. He said: "We had been confusing a lot of other climbers along the way as a stormtrooper was the last thing they had been expecting to see climbing Ben Nevis. "We handed out cards and told them my tale and they offered nothing but the most vocal support." Mr Broomhall also received donations from other walkers. Higher up Ben Nevis he had to negotiate thigh-deep snow. At the first of these snowfields there was some light relief when he and his walking companion had a snowball fight with other walkers. Mr Broomhall said: "The last snowfield held the summit and, with my heart swelling with pride, I let the flag fly and charged on to the summit. "We had made it. It was brilliant and I was so happy at making it after all the struggles and rallying needed to get myself there. "I was greeted by a cheer from the climbers there and planted the flag on the summit itself claiming it for the Empire." He added: "I love Scotland and I love Munros and this was a challenge that I enjoyed doing. "Scafell Pike is next. I've done the other two in armour, might as well do the third in it."

text: Ashley Broomhall trekked to the summit of 3,560 ft ( 1,085 m ) Snowdon in Snowdonia before tackling Ben Nevis . It took him seven hours to walk up and down the 4,406 ft ( 1,344 m ) Scottish peak near Fort William . On the way up he had a snowball fight with other walkers . He now plans to walk 3,208 ft ( 978 m ) Scafell Pike in the Lake District . Mr Broomhall , from Whitchurch in Shropshire , has been doing the walks to raise money for Cancer Research UK . He was inspired to take on the gruelling challenge after seeing the devastating impact of cancer on close friends and family members. He believes that every step he takes, and every pound he raises, contributes to vital research that could save lives in the future. His ascent of Snowdon, the highest peak in Wales, provided a challenging start to his mountaineering endeavours, offering stunning views of Snowdonia National Park despite periods of cloud and wind. The subsequent climb of Ben Nevis, the UK's highest mountain, proved to be an even more demanding test of his physical and mental fortitude. He recounted battling the notoriously unpredictable Scottish weather conditions, which ranged from clear spells to biting winds and snow flurries, even in what is considered late spring. The impromptu snowball fight on Ben Nevis's upper slopes offered a brief, memorable moment of camaraderie and fun amidst the arduous trek, highlighting the shared spirit among those conquering the formidable peak near Fort William. The descent, often as challenging as the ascent, required intense concentration and resilience, but the thought of the critical cause kept him focused. With two of the UK's three highest peaks now conquered, Mr Broomhall is eagerly anticipating his final challenge: Scafell Pike in the Lake District. Completing Scafell Pike will mark the culmination of his personal 'Three Peaks Challenge', an iconic feat that involves climbing the highest mountains in Scotland, England, and Wales within a set period. He understands that while Scafell Pike is the lowest of the three, it presents its own unique difficulties, including rugged terrain and potentially tricky navigation, especially if weather conditions are poor. Ashley Broomhall has set a fundraising target of £1,500 for Cancer Research UK and has already made significant progress towards that goal, having raised over £900 through a combination of online donations and sponsorship from friends, family, and local businesses. He expressed immense gratitude for the generosity shown by his supporters so far. "The support I've received has been overwhelming," said Mr Broomhall. "Knowing that people are backing me and contributing to such an important cause really motivates me to keep going, even when the climbs get tough. Every single donation helps fund groundbreaking research into new treatments and ultimately, a cure." He hopes that by sharing his journey, he can encourage more people to donate or consider their own fundraising challenges. Donations to Ashley Broomhall's efforts can be made via his dedicated JustGiving page, which can be found by searching for his name or his specific challenge details online. He remains committed to his fundraising mission, aiming to help contribute to a future where cancer no longer devastates lives.

text: An RAF Voyager A330 air-to-air refuelling aircraft will be refitted at a cost of about ¬£10m. The government says the move will save about ¬£775,000 a year as the plane will be cheaper than chartering flights. The SNP's Stewart Hosie said there needed to be "absolute transparency" to ensure the "best deal is made on behalf of the tax-payer". "This announcement comes just a week before the spending review when we can expect to hear of more cuts from the Tories, which are already hitting people hard," he added. Most government departments are facing budget cuts of at least 25% over the next four years. A source said the PM's flights, using either Royal Squadron planes or long haul charter, cost on average ¬£6,700 per flying hour and the RAF aircraft would cost ¬£2,000. It would be available for refuelling when it wasn't in use. The flight would also be available to the Royal family. When he was prime minister, Gordon Brown cancelled plans drawn up by his predecessor Tony Blair to buy two private jets, which had been nicknamed "Blair Force One" in reference to the aircraft used to fly the US president, Air Force One. The details of the new arrangements are expected to come at the strategic defence and security review on Monday. There is no definite timing for the plane to come into service but it could be as early as next year. A government spokesperson said; "As part of the government's defence review, we have been looking at ways to make better use of the RAF fleet to transport senior ministers and consequently deliver savings for taxpayers. "We have decided to adapt one of our existing Voyager aircraft so that, in addition to its primary air tanking role, it can transport Ministers and it will also be available for the Royal family to use."

text: The 19 year-old added 85 for the first wicket with Paul Horton (41) before Glamorgan claimed three quick wickets, two to teenager Lukas Carey. Dearden then dominated a stand of 90 with Mark Pettini (63 not out) before being bowled by spinner Andrew Salter. Pettini steered the Foxes to a second batting point underneath the lights. Dearden, who was dropped on one, survived a couple of run-out chances in his lengthy vigil of 211 balls. But it was a gritty performance from the home team after being put in to bat, in a battle of two teams who had lost their opening two fixtures by large margins. Salter claimed a second wicket, bowling Cameron Delport for 20, before Pettini and Lewis Hill accelerated against the new ball in a stand of 73. Leicestershire batsman Harry Dearden told BBC Radio Leicester: "I was very proud to get a career-best, I would have loved to have got to three figures but still very proud, it's been a really good day for us. "It was doing a bit early on, nipping around and swinging, you've just got to take as many balls as you can to get in and it was a good battle up top. "I just tried to knuckle down and be as disciplined as I could. It's good batting with Horts (Paul Horton), he's an experienced head and calms you down, and it's really good batting with Mark (Pettini), he keeps you level." Glamorgan spinner Andrew Salter told BBC Wales Sport: "I am happy to take those two wickets, though it won't come as a surprise that they didn't turn that much- one through the gate and one a bit fuller that hit a bit of rough. "It was more about trying to control the run-rate and I felt that if I built enough pressure there'd be some reward at the end of it, so hopefully I won't be needed too much more in the first innings. "For the majority of the day we bowled really well as a group, Lukas (Carey) bowled amazingly up top, the run-rate was 2.6 for most of the day and it wasn't until the end that they got away from us."

It was an innings of two halves, patiently accumulating runs against the new ball before accelerating with Mark Pettini in a partnership that put the visitors on the back foot. The early scares, being dropped and almost run out, only seemed to steel his resolve, as he focused on building a substantial total for his team. With Dearden gone, Leicestershire still needed to consolidate. Mark Pettini, who had played an excellent supporting role, then took on the mantle of primary aggressor. He found an able partner in Ned Eckersley, and the pair continued to build on the platform Dearden had established. Glamorgan, despite their earlier breakthroughs, found it difficult to dislodge Pettini, whose experience shone through. Lukas Carey, though expensive in patches, continued to pose a threat with his pace and bounce, while Andrew Salter tried to tie down the scoring with his accurate left-arm spin. The Welsh county's bowlers, however, struggled to maintain consistent pressure as the pitch flattened out under the floodlights. Pettini reached his own well-deserved hundred just before the close of play, guiding Leicestershire past the 400-run mark. They declared their innings at 415 for 7, giving their bowlers a brief spell at Glamorgan's openers before stumps. Sam Northeast and Nick Selman weathered the initial storm, but the Foxes' new ball bowlers, led by Chris Wright, made them play at everything. text: It was the first time the Commonwealth gold medallist had fought in front of his home crowd at a packed Meadowbank. "I didn't think it would be as quick as that," Taylor told BBC Scotland. "This boy is very special," said manager Barry McGuigan. We've got to take the right fights at the right time." The Hungarian Mate came into the contest with an impressive record with 17 wins in his 22 previous fights, but it was evident from the first bell that Taylor was more than a match for him. Taylor burst out of the corner and had Mate on the canvass with only 45 seconds on the clock. And when the Commonwealth Games champion caught Mate with a left hook to floor him for the second time the referee stepped in to stop him enduring any further punishment with only 85 seconds of the first round gone. The speed of victory caught Taylor by surprise who expected a stern test in front of his home crowd. "It was a pretty hostile atmosphere and when I seen him in the centre of the ring I could see it in his eyes that he was a wee bit scared. "I thought he would have come out a bit more but I caught him with a good shot and I felt that I was stronger than him." Taylor is managed by the former world champion Barry McGuigan who said there was little learned during the fight that they didn't already know about his boxer. "It was a pretty pointless exercise in one sense because Josh didn't get the sort of rounds we were expecting. But he is a tremendous puncher and and that guy (Mate) went down and wasn't getting up there is no doubt about it." McGuigan says they will now need to look for a tougher opponent next time around. "We know the calibre that Josh is but I am now thinking where are we going to go now. We need to get guys that are even better (than Mate) and just get him out again." Taylor says he wants to be back in the ring before the end of the year before he will even contemplate looking at any potential title fights. "I hope to be back in the ring before Christmas. I will only take a couple of days off before getting back into training, learning and developing." "Because of my amateur background I am at domestic level title already but obviously I need to develop as a professional and get rounds under your belt before you do that."

The packed Meadowbank Arena erupted in a deafening roar, a standing ovation for their hometown hero. text: Kathryn Trussler crafts sculptures from discarded consumer waste, including artificial turf and polystyrene. Her exhibition, opening at Elysium Gallery on May 19, was inspired by unique items found on Swansea beach. Ms. Trussler aims for her work to challenge the use of non-biodegradable materials for short-term purposes like packaging. She revealed the concept originated from what she initially perceived as a simple pile of pebbles. However, closer examination revealed they were old, weathered expanding foam pieces, stacked by decreasing size, reminiscent of the mass-produced 'Zen stones' art seen in medical offices or hotels.
label: T4

text: Six policemen died in a gunfight during an operation to evict the farmers from land they had been occupying. Eleven protesters were also killed. The deaths deepened political tensions in Paraguay and were used by congress to oust the left-wing President Fernando Lugo. Four men received sentences of between 18 and 30 years in jail, while a further seven men and women were given sentences of between four and six years. The court heard how the clashes occurred near the city of Curuguaty in Canindeyu province in the east of Paraguay when a group of around 250 riot police were sent to clear a group of around 70 subsistence farmers off a property belonging to an agricultural company called Campos Morumbi. The farmers had occupied the land as part of a demonstration in favour of agrarian reform. The Paraguayan prosecution service did not investigate the deaths of the farmers who died during the eviction. Local and international human rights organizations alleged there had been judicial irregularities during the trial. Five of the accused had gone on hunger strike for more than 30 days. √¢‚Ç ̈‚ÄπLand ownership has long formed the basis for bloody disputes in Paraguay. According to the 2008 census, 2.6% of landowners hold 85.5% of Paraguay's land while 91.4% of small farmers, with properties smaller than 20 hectare, hold only 6% of the agricultural land. Campaigners for agrarian reform have focussed on large agricultural conglomerates involved in the export of soy as being the main cause of the unequal land distribution in Paraguay. The events at Curuguaty became the basis for the opposition Colorado Party to push for the impeachment of President Lugo whom they blamed for the killings.
label: T1

text: Six policemen died in a gunfight during an operation to evict the farmers from land they had been occupying . Eleven protesters were also killed . The deaths deepened political tensions in Paraguay and were used by congress to oust the left - wing President Fernando Lugo . Four men received sentences of between 18 and 30 years in jail This tragic incident, which unfolded on June 15, 2012, at the Campos Morumbi estate in Curuguaty, became widely known as the Curuguaty Massacre. The land in question was fiercely disputed, with landless farmers claiming it as state property intended for agrarian reform. The subsequent judicial process was highly controversial; human rights organizations and international observers heavily criticized the trial of the eleven farmers, alleging a lack of due process and insufficient evidence linking them to the police deaths. The massacre provided the immediate catalyst for the Paraguayan congress to orchestrate a rapid impeachment of President Fernando Lugo. His swift removal, days after the killings, was seen as a politically motivated move to reverse his land reform agenda. Several regional governments, including MERCOSUR and UNASUR, condemned Lugo's ouster as a 'parliamentary coup,' leading to Paraguay's temporary suspension from these blocs. Despite the initial convictions handed down in 2016, a major turning point occurred in July 2017. The Supreme Court of Justice of Paraguay annulled the sentences against the eleven convicted farmers, including the four, citing a lack of concrete evidence and procedural errors. This landmark decision led to their immediate release, marking a complex legal saga that underscored the deep-seated land conflicts and political polarization in Paraguay. The Curuguaty case remains a poignant symbol of the ongoing struggle for land rights and justice in the nation's history.
label: T2

text: A judge in Paraguay has sentenced 11 subsistence farmers to up to 30 years in jail for the deaths of police officers during a land reform protest four years ago.
label: T3

text: A violent clash resulted in the deaths of six police officers and eleven protestors during an operation to remove farmers from land they had occupied. These fatalities escalated political tensions in Paraguay, subsequently leading to President Fernando Lugo's removal from office by congress. In the aftermath, four men were sentenced to 18 to 30 years in prison, with an additional seven individuals (men and women) receiving jail terms of four to six years. Testimony revealed the confrontation took place near Curuguaty, in eastern Paraguay's Canindeyu province. Approximately 250 riot police were dispatched to clear about 70 subsistence farmers from a Campos Morumbi agricultural company property. The farmers had been occupying the land to advocate for agrarian reform. Notably, the Paraguayan prosecution service failed to investigate the farmers' deaths, and both local and international human rights organizations raised concerns about judicial irregularities throughout the trial. Furthermore, five of the defendants undertook a hunger strike lasting over 30 days. Unequal land ownership has historically fueled violent conflicts in Paraguay. A 2008 census highlighted this disparity: a mere 2.6% of landowners control 85.5% of the country's land, while 91.4% of small farmers (with holdings under 20 hectares) possess only 6% of agricultural land. Advocates for agrarian reform largely attribute this imbalance to major agricultural conglomerates specializing in soy exports. The Curuguaty incident then served as the catalyst for the opposition Colorado Party to initiate impeachment proceedings against President Lugo, holding him responsible for the fatalities.
label: T4

text: Ninety-three of the retailer's 125 stores will close, with the rest remaining open while buyers are sought. If administrator KPMG cannot find buyers, the remaining stores will also shut. The chain employed 1,658 people. The chain was sold to Greybull Capital last year by supermarket Morrisons, which has said it would offer jobs to ex-My Local staff. It has struggled to compete in the cut-throat grocery sector, which is caught in a fierce price war. My Local, formally known as Morrisons' M Local, was sold to Greybull for √Ç¬£25m in a deal fronted by retail veteran Mike Greene, who appeared on Channel 4 show The Secret Millionaire. Earlier this month My Local said that administrators had been put on notice to take over running the business. Last week Morrisons offered a lifeline to My Local staff, saying it wanted to offer them jobs in its supermarkets if there were store closures. Mr Greene said: "The last nine months has been one of the toughest retail trading periods that I have ever experienced and My Local has faced intense competition. "The management team has been unable to return the business to profitability. For that I am truly sorry." Mark Orton, partner at KPMG and joint administrator, said: "Management have faced tough trading conditions and despite their best efforts to improve performance, My Local was ultimately unable to return to viability. "Although the majority of stores have now closed, we are in active discussions with a number of interested parties in relation to both the remaining 32 premises that are trading and a small number of those that have closed," he said. The failure of My Local comes at a difficult time for the retail sector, following on from the failures of BHS and Austin Reed. On Tuesday, the owners of fashion firm Store Twenty One said they would push for a restructure that could result in store closures and job losses.
label: T1

text: Ninety - three of the retailer 's 125 stores will close , with the rest remaining open while buyers are sought . If administrator KPMG can not find buyers , the remaining stores will also shut . The chain employed 1,658 people . The chain was sold to Greybull Capital last year by supermarket Morrisons , which has said it would offer jobs to ex - My Local staff . It has struggled since being acquired by private equity firm Greybull Capital in September 2015. The chain, formerly Morrisons M Local, was sold off by the supermarket giant as part of a strategic shift away from smaller convenience formats to focus on its larger superstores. At the time of the sale, Morrisons provided significant financial support to Greybull Capital, including a loan of up to £25 million, to help stabilize the business and facilitate its turnaround. However, the investment proved insufficient to reverse its fortunes in an increasingly competitive market dominated by established players like Tesco Express and Sainsbury's Local, as well as discounters. The challenges faced by the former Morrisons' M Local stores under Greybull Capital’s stewardship were multifaceted. High operating costs, coupled with intense price competition and shifts in consumer shopping habits, created a difficult trading environment. Despite efforts to rebrand and reposition the stores as ‘My Local’, aiming for a community-focused offering, the chain failed to gain significant traction or achieve sustainable profitability. The decision to appoint KPMG as administrators came after a period of intense financial pressure, leaving no viable path forward without significant restructuring. KPMG's immediate priority has been to manage the closure of the 93 unprofitable stores and to seek buyers for the remaining 32. Sources close to the administration process indicate that finding a single buyer for the remaining portfolio might be challenging, suggesting that individual or smaller clusters of stores could be sold off to other retailers or convenience store operators. The closure process will unfortunately result in the loss of a significant number of the 1,658 jobs, though Morrisons' proactive offer to re-employ former My Local staff, where possible, provides some relief to those affected. This gesture by Morrisons highlights its ongoing commitment, having initially established the convenience arm and then divested it. The collapse of My Local underscores the difficulties even established players face in the convenience sector. For Greybull Capital, this represents a significant setback, adding to their mixed portfolio of investments. The future of the remaining 32 stores hinges entirely on KPMG’s ability to secure buyers within a reasonable timeframe, failing which, they too will inevitably shut, marking the complete disappearance of the My Local brand from the high street, less than a year after its high-profile launch under Greybull.
label: T2

Should these efforts fail, those stores too will cease operations. The company had a workforce of 1,658 individuals. Morrisons, a supermarket chain, sold My Local to Greybull Capital last year and has since committed to offering positions to former My Local employees. The retailer found it difficult to compete in the fiercely competitive and price-war-ridden grocery market. Formerly known as Morrisons' M Local, My Local was acquired by Greybull for £25 million. This acquisition was spearheaded by Mike Greene, an experienced figure in retail who gained public recognition from his appearance on Channel 4's The Secret Millionaire. My Local had indicated earlier this month that administrators were alerted to assume control of the business. Just last week, Morrisons extended a helping hand to My Local's staff, proposing job opportunities within its own supermarkets in the event of store closures. Mike Greene expressed his regret, stating that the past nine months constituted "one of the toughest retail trading periods" he had ever encountered, with My Local confronting "intense competition." He added that the management team was "unable to return the business to profitability," for which he was "truly sorry." Mark Orton, a partner at KPMG and joint administrator, commented that the management faced "tough trading conditions," and despite their "best efforts to improve performance," My Local ultimately "was unable to return to viability." He confirmed that while most stores have now ceased operations, KPMG is engaged in "active discussions with a number of interested parties" regarding both the 32 remaining operational premises and a select few that have already shut down. My Local's collapse highlights a challenging period for the retail industry, coming after the bankruptcies of BHS and Austin Reed. text: Engineers on the Thameslink Programme uncovered the former ticket hall and platforms of Southwark Park station. The long-lost station only served passengers from 1902 to 1915 before shutting for good. The ¬£6.5bn Thameslink Programme is rebuilding railway lines from New Cross Gate through London Bridge to Blackfriars and St Pancras. Located on a viaduct above Rotherhithe New Road, Southwark Park was one of several stations in the area, including Spa Road, which closed because of competition from trams and buses and the outbreak of World War One. The station was discovered as engineers constructed the Bermondsey Dive Under, which will see two Victorian viaducts partially-demolished and rebuilt to allow trains from south east London and Kent to dive down, under a new route carrying Thameslink services from Croydon. Project manager Greg Thornett said: "We uncovered the footings for the former platforms while we were preparing the top of the viaduct for new track and we are now working up in the roof space of the former ticket hall to fill in the old skylights, ready to carry the final track alignment. "Much of the existing stretch of viaduct will be replaced by the ramps into and out of the new dive under, but the arch that used to house the old booking hall will remain."
label: T1

text: Engineers on the Thameslink Programme uncovered the former ticket hall and platforms of Southwark Park station . The long - lost station only served passengers from 1902 to 1915 before shutting for good . The ¬£6.5bn Thameslink Programme is rebuilding railway lines from New Cross Gate through Engineers on the Thameslink Programme uncovered the former ticket hall and platforms of Southwark Park station . The long - lost station only served passengers from 1902 to 1915 before shutting for good . The £6.5bn Thameslink Programme is rebuilding railway lines from New Cross Gate through London Bridge and Blackfriars, extending northwards to St Pancras International. This massive railway upgrade is part of the larger Thameslink Programme, designed to transform north-south travel across London and the South East. The £6.5bn investment aims to increase capacity and improve connectivity significantly, allowing for more frequent and longer trains to run directly through the city centre. The uncovering of Southwark Park station highlights the historical layers that engineers encounter during such ambitious modern infrastructure projects. The Thameslink Programme involves extensive remodelling of key stations, including London Bridge, and the creation of new railway infrastructure to support this enhanced service. Ultimately, it will link a wider range of destinations from Brighton in the south to Peterborough and Cambridge in the north, providing seamless and reliable journeys through the capital. This vital transport scheme addresses growing passenger demand, promising reduced congestion and a more efficient rail network for millions of commuters and travellers, ensuring the railway system is fit for the future.

text: Rail workers have discovered a south London "ghost" station which closed a century ago.
label: T3

text: During the extensive Thameslink Programme, engineers have unearthed the forgotten ticket hall and platforms of Southwark Park station. This long-vanished station operated briefly from 1902 until its permanent closure in 1915. The £6.5 billion Thameslink initiative is a major redevelopment effort, rebuilding railway lines that extend from New Cross Gate through London Bridge to Blackfriars and St Pancras. Perched on a viaduct above Rotherhithe New Road, Southwark Park was among several local stations, including Spa Road, that ceased operations. Their closures were primarily due to increasing competition from trams and buses, exacerbated by the outbreak of World War One. The discovery occurred as crews constructed the Bermondsey Dive Under. This project involves the partial demolition and reconstruction of two Victorian viaducts, allowing trains from southeast London and Kent to descend beneath a new route intended for Thameslink services from Croydon. Project manager Greg Thornett explained: "We found the old platform foundations while preparing the viaduct's upper section for new track. Currently, we're working in the former ticket hall's roof area, sealing existing skylights to accommodate the final track alignment." He added that much of the existing viaduct segment will be replaced by the new dive under's access ramps, but the original arch that housed the booking hall will be preserved.

text: The assaults happened in Castlemilk, Glasgow, at about 20:05 on Friday. Police said the boy was walking in Ardencraig Quadrant near its junction with Ardencraig Drive when he was seriously assaulted. His 52-year-old father, who saw the incident, was attacked when he ran over to help. The pair were both treated in hospital for facial injuries. They were later released. The two suspects were described as being white, aged between 17 and 21, and wearing dark clothes. Det Con Peter McFarlane said: "These were violent and unprovoked attacks and officers are currently carrying out house-to-house inquiries and reviewing CCTV images in their ongoing efforts to identify the two responsible. "Although we believe this to be a random incident, there will be additional patrols in the area to provide public reassurance." In a separate incident, at about 20:00 on Saturday, a 23-year-old man was assaulted in Partick in what police believe was a targeted attack. The man was walking along Exeter Drive, near its junction with Dumbarton Road, when a man got out of a passing car and seriously assaulted him. The suspect then got back into his car and drove off. Passers-by went to help and he was taken to hospital to be treated for head and facial injuries. He was later released. Police said there was no description of the suspect available, but he was driving a grey BMW 3 Series saloon. Det Con David Hardie said: "We believe this to be a targeted attack and officers are carrying out inquiries in the area today and checking CCTV footage in an effort to gather more information on the circumstances surrounding this attack and the man responsible." Detectives have appealed for anyone with information about either attack to contact them.

text: He was asked if a change in the law was being considered as part of a review of marriage laws. "Not as far as I'm aware and I've certainly no intention of doing so," he told the BBC's Sunday Politics show. The government was looking into humanist marriages in England and Wales, he said. Humanism is a secular philosophy. Humanist weddings are not legally recognised in England, Wales and Northern Ireland - but they are legal in Scotland. The Daily Mail reported on Tuesday that ministers had ordered a rethink of wedding laws, which could allow naturists to conduct weddings if the rules were changed. It claimed a paper had been published by Mr Grayling which confirmed groups who have expressed an interest in changing wedding laws included British Naturism, the organisation that campaigns for a greater understanding and acceptance of outdoor nudism. But Mr Grayling told the BBC: "It hasn't been ordered by me I can tell you that." The justice secretary stressed there was a difference between someone "expressing an interest" and "something actually happening". "No nude marriage right now as far as I'm concerned," he told the BBC.
label: T1

text: He was asked if a change in the law was being considered as part of a review of marriage laws . " Not as far as I 'm aware and I 've certainly no intention of doing so , " he told the BBC . The unnamed government official's remarks came amid a broader review of family legislation. He clarified that the current review, covering England and Wales, primarily focuses on administrative and procedural updates to marriage and divorce processes, not on altering the fundamental definition of marriage itself. He emphasized that any changes would aim to streamline the system, making it more efficient and accessible for citizens, rather than instigating major societal shifts. Separate legal frameworks apply in Scotland and Northern Ireland, he noted, and the current review does not extend to these devolved areas. "Our focus is firmly on practical improvements to the existing law," he reiterated to the BBC, "not on initiating a debate about what marriage is." He further explained that the review seeks to simplify legal requirements, such as those related to wedding venues and notice periods, ensuring they are suitable for modern life. There is no intention to redefine marriage or extend its scope beyond its current legal interpretation. The review process involves extensive consultation with legal experts, religious groups, and other stakeholders across England and Wales to ensure that any proposed amendments are well-considered and reflect public need without undermining the established principles of marriage. He stressed the government's commitment to providing a clear and stable legal framework for all families.
label: T2

text: Mr Mills had been deputy chairman of the group designated the lead "out" campaign by the Electoral Commission. He has previously claimed the campaign was torn by internal feuding. He was reported to have been on the verge of quitting in February when Labour MP Kate Hoey joined a rival out campaign. In his resignation letter, the home shopping magnate said he had "come to believe that it would be useful and more effective for the Leave campaign if there was a strong and independent Labour voice for the arguments to leave the EU". "I can now focus fully on my role as ... director of Labour Leave, and create that distinctive voice," he said. "In the run up to the vote on 23 June, Labour Leave will provide a compelling and robust left-of-centre case for leaving the EU." The vast majority of Labour MPs are in favour of Britain remaining in the EU - with about a dozen campaigning for an exit. Labour former minister Frank Field has warned the party it risks losing "a swathe" of voters to UKIP by campaigning to remain in the EU. Mr Mills, who played a leading role in the 1975 referendum campaign against EU membership, has also been critical of Jeremy Corbyn's decision to back staying in. He said: "I hope this decision will be a transformative first step to motivating Labour people who are still unsure how they will vote, to vote Leave in June to secure a better, fairer future for this country. "Labour Leave will continue to work with Vote Leave, as well as other Leave campaigns across the piece, to secure a stronger future for the UK outside the EU." Vote Leave was the organisation chosen by the Electoral Commission to take the lead in making the case for Britain to leave the European Union. It is headed by big Conservative names Boris Johnson and Michael Gove and Labour MP Gisela Stuart with support from Lib Dem and UKIP figures, as well as business people. Subscribe to the BBC News EU referendum email newsletter and get a weekly round-up of news, features and analysis on the campaign sent straight to your inbox.
label: T1

text: Mr Mills had been deputy chairman of the group designated the lead " out " campaign by the Electoral Commission . He has previously claimed the campaign was torn by internal feuding . He was reported to have been on the verge of quitting in February when Labour MP Kate Hoey joined a rival out campaign . In his resignation letter , the home shopping magnate said he had " come to believe that it would be useful and more effective for the broader 'Leave' campaign, and indeed the national interest, if I were to step aside from my current role. My decision is not taken lightly and stems from a growing conviction that the internal dynamics within our designated lead campaign, as sanctioned by the Electoral Commission, have unfortunately reached a point where they risk undermining our collective efforts. Despite tireless work and dedication from many individuals, the persistent internal feuding and divergent strategic approaches have, regrettably, become an increasingly debilitating distraction. These divisions, which I have previously highlighted, prevent the unified and forceful message that is absolutely essential if we are to convince the British public that a future outside the European Union is not only viable but preferable. The emergence of multiple, often competing, 'out' campaigns, exemplified by the participation of figures such as Labour MP Kate Hoey in an alternative platform, further fragments our message and dilutes the impact of the arguments for departure from the EU. While diversity of opinion is a hallmark of a healthy democracy, the current landscape within the 'Leave' movement risks confusing voters and playing into the hands of those who wish to remain. For the 'Leave' campaign to succeed, it requires absolute clarity of purpose, a laser-like focus on the core arguments for sovereignty and economic opportunity, and above all, a cohesive and disciplined leadership that speaks with one voice. It needs to be perceived by the public as a unified force, not a collection of warring factions. It is my earnest hope that by removing myself from the immediate leadership structure, it may create an opportunity for a renewed focus on unity and strategic coherence. My commitment to seeing Britain leave the European Union remains absolute, and I will continue to support the broader 'Leave' cause from outside this specific leadership role. I wish the campaign every success in the vital months ahead. The stakes for our nation are incredibly high, and it is imperative that the 'Leave' side presents an irrefutable case for a brighter, independent future for the United Kingdom.
label: T2

text: Labour donor John Mills has quit the cross-party Vote Leave campaign saying he wanted to concentrate on making his party's case for Brexit.
label: T3

text: Mr. Mills had served as deputy chairman for the primary "out" campaign, officially recognized by the Electoral Commission. He had previously alleged that the campaign was plagued by internal disputes. Reports indicated he was close to resigning in February when Labour MP Kate Hoey joined a competing "out" group. In his letter of resignation, the home shopping executive explained his belief that a robust and independent Labour perspective advocating for leaving the EU would prove more beneficial and effective for the Leave campaign. He noted that he could now fully devote himself to his role as director of Labour Leave, thereby cultivating that distinct voice. He added that, leading up to the 23 June vote, Labour Leave intended to present a powerful and well-reasoned left-of-centre case for Britain's exit from the EU. The overwhelming majority of Labour Members of Parliament favor Britain remaining within the EU, with only approximately twelve actively campaigning for departure. Former Labour minister Frank Field cautioned the party that its stance on remaining in the EU risked alienating a significant number of voters, potentially losing them to UKIP. Mr. Mills, who played a key role in the 1975 referendum campaign against European Economic Community membership, has also expressed disapproval of Jeremy Corbyn's decision to support staying in. Mr. Mills voiced his hope that his choice would be a transformative initial step in encouraging Labour supporters, who are still undecided, to vote Leave in June to secure a better, fairer future for the country. He also stated that Labour Leave would continue its collaboration with Vote Leave, as well as other pro-exit campaigns across the spectrum, to ensure a stronger future for the UK outside the EU. Vote Leave was the organization chosen by the Electoral Commission to spearhead the argument for Britain's withdrawal from the European Union. It is led by prominent Conservative figures Boris Johnson and Michael Gove, alongside Labour MP Gisela Stuart, and receives backing from Liberal Democrat and UKIP personalities, as well as business professionals. text: Logan Murdoch suffered serious injuries in the crash and was not breathing when the Great North Air Ambulance team arrived. Hayley Murdoch, 29, and Sheila Dixon, 71, both from Carlisle, died following the collision at Newby Cross in 2016. Dr Laura Duffy called Logan, who made a full recovery, a "ray of sunshine". Logan suffered an "internal decapitation", which is a separation of the spinal column from the base of the skull, as well as brain injuries, a punctured lung and a broken collar bone. Dr Duffy said with the injuries he sustained, he was "unlikely to survive". The young boy was resuscitated at the roadside before being put into a medically-induced coma at the scene. He was also given blood en route to hospital and went on to make a full recovery. John Murdoch, Logan's father, said: "The doctor said that Logan was a very rare case. "He said in all his 25 years as a neurosurgeon, only two other people had been brought to him alive after being 'internally decapitated'. "One of those died, and the other was severely paralysed. He is a very lucky boy. GNAAS saved Logan's life." Logan, his father and grandmother Karen Rooney visited the ambulance's airbase to meet Dr Laura Duffy and paramedic Colin Clark who attended the crash.

text: Logan Murdoch suffered serious injuries in the crash and was not breathing when the Great North Air Ambulance team arrived . Hayley Murdoch , 29 , and Sheila Dixon , 71 , both from Carlisle , died following the collision at Newby Cross in 2016 . Dr Laura Duffy called Logan , years after that harrowing day, to marvel at his incredible journey back to health. She vividly recalled the scene at Newby Cross, describing it as one of the most challenging she had ever encountered. Logan had been clinically dead, but through the swift, coordinated efforts of the emergency services – the first responders, paramedics, and the air ambulance crew – he was resuscitated at the roadside. He was then airlifted to the Royal Victoria Infirmary in Newcastle in a critical condition, placed in an induced coma, and remained there for several weeks, fighting for his life. His family, already reeling from the devastating loss of Hayley Murdoch and Sheila Dixon, braced themselves for the worst, enduring agonizing days and nights by his bedside. Against all odds, Logan began a slow, arduous recovery. Dr Duffy recounted the initial prognosis, which had been bleak, suggesting severe brain damage and long-term disability were highly probable. Yet, Logan’s resilience and determination, coupled with exceptional medical care, defied these expectations. His rehabilitation was extensive, involving months of physiotherapy, speech therapy, and psychological support to help him come to terms with the traumatic event and the profound grief of losing his mother and grandmother. The call from Dr Duffy was a poignant reminder of how close he came to joining them. She told him that his survival was nothing short of miraculous, a testament to the life-saving work done in those critical moments at the crash site near Carlisle. Logan, now a vocal advocate for the Great North Air Ambulance, often reflects on that day, acknowledging that without their rapid response, he would not be here today to share his story or remember his beloved Hayley Murdoch and Sheila Dixon. The scars, both physical and emotional, remain, but so does an immense gratitude for the second chance at life he received.

text: The suspects are accused of smuggling large quantities of cocaine from Colombia to Europe in sailing boats. Officials said among those arrested is a commander of the Colombian left-wing rebel group, Farc. Police said the suspects were part of a transatlantic drugs ring run by the 'Ndrangheta crime syndicate, which has its base in southern Italy. The investigation, dubbed Santa Fe, was carried out jointly by Italian agents, members of the US Drug Enforcement Administration and Spain's Guardia Civil. Officials said the drug ring operated in countries as far flung as Argentina, Brazil, Colombia, Dominican Republic, Spain and Montenegro. The identity of the Farc commander has not yet been made public, but Colombian media said it would soon be revealed. The rebel group derives much of its finances from cocaine production and trafficking. Officials said that in the course of their investigations they seized a total of four tonnes of cocaine. One of the largest seizures was in the night of 25-26 August last year when the Spanish navy stopped a sailboat heading for the Italian coast. They found 856kg of cocaine on board. They said that the drugs were smuggled from Colombia mainly into southern Italian port of Gioia Tauro in Calabria, but that they were also taken to ports in northern Italy such as Vado Ligure, Livorno and Genoa. Police say the 'Ndrangheta operates the biggest cocaine smuggling network in Europe.

text: The suspects are accused of smuggling large quantities of cocaine from Colombia to Europe in sailing boats . Officials said among those arrested is a commander of the Colombian left - wing rebel group , Farc . Police said the suspects were part of a transatlantic drugs ring run by the ' Ndrangheta a powerful organized crime syndicate based in Calabria, southern Italy. This operation highlights the growing partnership between Colombian drug producers, particularly remnant factions associated with the dissolved Farc insurgency, and the sophisticated distribution networks of European mafias. Investigators revealed that the cocaine shipments originated in remote jungle labs in Colombia, often in areas previously controlled by the Farc, who either directly cultivated coca or levied 'taxes' on independent producers for safe passage and processing. The sailing boats were chosen for their ability to blend in with legitimate maritime traffic, making them less conspicuous than large cargo vessels, and for their capacity to carry substantial loads without attracting undue attention. The routes typically involved crossing the Atlantic, often utilizing strategically located island nations as re-provisioning points before reaching European ports, predominantly in Spain and Portugal, for onward distribution across the continent. This particular bust involved meticulous intelligence gathering over several years, a collaborative effort spanning multiple law enforcement agencies. A significant breakthrough came with intelligence shared by The US Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA), which had been tracking the cartel's activities and its nexus with various Colombian narco-trafficking groups. Authorities in Colombia and Italy, alongside Europol and other European police forces, executed synchronized raids following the DEA's lead. Among the arrests were key logistical managers in Europe and several suppliers in South America. The Farc commander arrested in Colombia was reportedly a crucial link, responsible for ensuring the quality and quantity of the cocaine supplied and facilitating its transport to coastal rendezvous points. Further investigations are underway in the region, including in areas near Santa Fe, where some of the preliminary processing and logistics for the illicit drug trade are suspected to have taken place, demonstrating the intricate web of this criminal enterprise. The scale of the operation underscores the global reach of organized crime and the persistent challenge posed by the drug trade.

text: Senioli , a scrum - half for Italian side Treviso pointed and smiled at Scott Williams , who plays for Welsh team Scarlets , as he ran towards the line during a crucial game in Italy . The Treviso player stumbled, his momentum broken, and the ball, which he had been cradling loosely in anticipation of the score, was dislodged. It bounced once, tantalisingly close to the whitewash, before a Scarlets forward, arriving belatedly but opportunistically, dived on it, securing the turnover. The collective groan from the Italian crowd was almost as loud as the roar of relief from the small contingent of travelling Welsh supporters. Senioli, still sprawled on the turf, looked up in disbelief, the earlier smile replaced by a grimace of frustration. Scott Williams, quickly back on his feet, simply nodded, a silent testament to the high stakes of this cross-border encounter. This single moment, a testament to Williams's grit, shifted the momentum. Treviso, who had been dominating, suddenly looked rattled, while Scarlets, buoyed by the miraculous defensive stop, found a new surge of energy. The game, critical for both sides' European aspirations, hung finely in the balance, a true showcase of the intensity of rugby between Italy and Wales.

text: The weapon was one of a pair of daggers discovered by British archaeologist Howard Carter in 1925 within the burial wrappings of the teenaged king. The origin of its unrusted iron blade has baffled scientists because such metalwork was rare in ancient Egypt. Tutankhamun was mummified more than 3,300 years ago. Italian and Egyptian researchers used "a non-invasive X-ray technique" to confirm the composition of the iron without damaging it, according to a study published in the journal of Meteoritics and Planetary Science. Tutankhamun's beard glued back on 'High chance' of chamber in Tut's tomb "Meteoritic iron is clearly indicated by the presence of a high percentage of nickel," the study's main author, Daniela Comelli, said. The researchers say the presence of iron - along with levels of nickel and cobalt - "strongly suggests an extraterrestrial origin". They compared the composition of the dagger to known meteorites within 2,000km around the Red Sea coast of Egypt, and found that one in particular - which landed 150 miles (240km) west of Alexandria - contained similar levels of nickel and cobalt. Ancient Egyptians attached great significance to meteoritic iron for the production of fine ornamental or ceremonial objects, the researchers say. "They were aware that these rare chunks of iron fell from the sky already in the 13th [Century] BCE, anticipating Western culture by more than two millennia," they write in their findings. The high manufacturing quality of the blade in comparison with other simple-shaped meteoritic iron artefacts "suggests a significant mastery of ironworking in Tutankhamun's time", they say. The dagger - which features a decorated gold handle and a gold sheath with a floral lily motif on one side and a feather pattern on the other - is now on display at the Egyptian Museum in Cairo. iWonder: How do you solve the mystery of Tutankhamun's death?

text: The weapon was one of a pair of daggers discovered by British archaeologist Howard Carter in 1925 within the burial wrappings of the teenaged king . The origin of its unrusted iron blade has baffled scientists because such metalwork was rare in ancient Egypt . Tutankhamun was mummified more than 3,300 years ago . Italian and Egyptian researchers used " a non - invasive X - ray technique " to confirm that the iron blade was indeed of extraterrestrial origin, likely from a meteorite. The study, published in the journal Meteoritics and Planetary Science, analyzed the blade's elemental composition, revealing high levels of nickel and cobalt, elements typically found in iron meteorites but rare in terrestrial iron. This groundbreaking finding provided a definitive answer to a long-standing archaeological mystery that had puzzled experts since Howard Carter’s initial discovery of the dagger in Tutankhamun's tomb. The sophisticated X-ray fluorescence analysis, conducted by researchers from the Polytechnic University of Milan and the Egyptian Museum in Cairo, eliminated any doubt about the blade's celestial source. The presence of nickel, in particular, was a key indicator, as iron extracted from ores on Earth rarely contains such high concentrations. This suggests that ancient Egyptian metallurgists, despite their advanced skills in working with gold and copper, utilized this unique, readily available raw material from the sky. The fact that the dagger has remained largely uncorroded for over three millennia further supports its meteoric origin, as meteoric iron is often more resistant to rust due to its unique crystalline structure and composition. This discovery sheds new light on the technological capabilities and available resources in ancient Egypt during the New Kingdom period. It implies that the Egyptians were not only aware of falling 'sky-iron' but also possessed the skills to forge it into intricate objects of immense value, fit for a pharaoh like Tutankhamun. The cultural significance of such a material, literally descended from the heavens, would have been profound, adding to the mystique and power attributed to the young king. The other dagger found alongside it was made of gold, contrasting sharply with the 'celestial' iron one, highlighting the distinct and perhaps revered nature of the iron blade. This research emphasizes the interdisciplinary approach needed to unravel the secrets of ancient civilizations, combining archaeology, art history, and modern scientific analysis to provide unprecedented insights into the past of Tut and his people.

text: A dagger, part of a pair, was uncovered in 1925 by British archaeologist Howard Carter, tucked within the funerary linens of the young pharaoh Tutankhamun. Daniela Comelli, the study's lead author, stated that "a significant nickel content unequivocally points to meteoritic iron." The team proposed that the combined levels of iron, nickel, and cobalt "strongly suggest an extraterrestrial origin" for the metal. According to the researchers, ancient Egyptians highly valued meteoritic iron, frequently using it for crafting exquisite ornamental or ceremonial items. Their findings indicate that Egyptians in the 13th century BCE already recognized that these unusual iron fragments descended from the heavens, a realization that predated Western understanding by over two millennia. The blade's superior craftsmanship, especially when contrasted with simpler meteoritic iron artifacts, "implies a remarkable proficiency in ironworking during Tutankhamun's reign," the team noted. This ornate dagger, boasting a decorated gold handle and a gold sheath adorned with a floral lily design on one face and a feather pattern on the other, is presently exhibited at the Egyptian Museum in Cairo.
